description: Nikola Petrak, pressured by Directorate officials and unrest reports, authorizes a citywide blackout, suspending all BCI oversight to stop further system breaches and give the Council time to regroup.

Residents awaken to a total blackout of BCI scoring, surveillance, and digital communications. Grassroots neighborhood assemblies begin to form, taking charge of local order in the absence of digital oversight.
Community groups self-organize for mutual assistance, debating whether life without BCI offers a better future. Early signs of restored trust and local cooperation emerge.
In an emergency session, Council factions learn the Directorate orchestrated the blackout to halt data losses and suppress potential evidence, straining internal trust.
Spurred by new civic assemblies, residents demand a referendum to decide the fate of the BCI. Council authority is at historic lows as public debate intensifies.
